title-group.article-title: Experimental assessment of the dynamic stiffness of a fault-tolerant fly-by-wire hydraulic actuator

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy

abstract.p: The stiffness of an actuator depends on the closed-loop position control (architecture and parameters), on the load frequency, and, for fault-tolerant actuators, on the operative mode. The stiffness response is of basic importance for the design of actuators for primary flight controls, especially for high-performance aircrafts. Actually, during flight conditions characterized by high speed and high angle-of-attack, the dynamic interactions between aircraft structure, actuator, and aerodynamic loads can induce aeroservoelastic effects, which, if not controlled, can imply performance degradation and even instability. The study and the compensation of such concerns require the assessment of the resonant frequencies of the aeroservoelastic system, which can be performed only by characterizing the dynamic stiffness of the actuator. This article reports the experimental activities carried out for the characterization of the stiffness response of a fault-tolerant fly-by-wire actuator for the primary flight controls of a modern jet trainer, starting from the feasibility studies of the experiments up to the execution of the vibration tests. The actuator stiffness performance is evaluated in different fail-operative modes by artificially injecting hydraulic and electrical failures, and the experimental data are interpreted by means of an LTI model of the flight actuator, highlighting and discussing the effects that the failures induce on the stiffness performance.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
The variation of the load applied to a position-controlled actuator implies a variation of the actuator position. The ratio between the load variation and the actuator displacement is known as actuator stiffness. The study and the characterization of this actuator performance, essentially depending on the load frequency and the closed-loop control architecture and parameters, plays a key role in the design of fly-by-wire flight control systems (FBW/FCS), since harmful effects can result from the interactions between actuator, structural dynamics, and unsteady aerodynamic loads [1–3]. Actually, FBW aircraft envelopes are typically characterized by high speed and high angle-of-attack [4], and aeroservoelastic concerns derived from flutter, gusts, or buffeting must be predicted, compensated, and controlled to avoid performance degradation or even instability [5]. The typical approach for compensating these adverse interactions is to implement notch filters on the feedback path of the FCS inertial sensors (Fig. 1), aiming to introduce an adequate attenuation at the resonant frequencies of the aeroservoelastic system [1, 6, 7], and it is clear that the effectiveness of this strategy strongly depends on the knowledge of the stiffness response of the actuators. Fig. 1
Aeroservoelastic interaction in FBW aircrafts

Many authors pointed out the importance of investigating the flight actuator stiffness performance. Some of them demonstrated that the choice of the stability margins for an aeroservoelastic system can be significantly less conservative if detailed models taking into account actuator nonlinearities are used for the closed-loop control design [8, 9]. Others focused their attention on the improvement of the stiffness performance via closed-loop control [10, 11]. However, scarce literature information is available about fault-tolerant actuators (typically employed for primary flight controls), with particular reference to the effects that the failures can imply on the stiffness performance.

This article reports the experimental activities carried out at the Department of Aerospace Engineering of the University of Pisa for the study and the characterization of the stiffness response of a fault-tolerant actuator employed for the primary flight controls of a modern FBW jet trainer, starting from the feasibility studies of the experiments, up to the execution of the vibration tests. The actuator stiffness performance is evaluated in different fail-operative modes,1 by artificially injecting hydraulic and electrical failures, and the experimental data are interpreted by means of a linear time-invariant (LTI) model of the flight actuator, highlighting and discussing the effects that the failures induce on the stiffness performance.

sec.title: 2.1 Flight actuator
sec.p:
The tested actuator is a fault-tolerant servo-hydraulic actuator used for the primary flight controls of a modern FBW jet trainer, Fig. 2. The actuator power unit is composed of a tandem cylinder supplied by two independent hydraulic lines, while the fluid power control is obtained by a single-spool servovalve driven by a quadruplex-coil direct-drive electrical motor (direct-drive valve, DDV). The level of redundancy allows the actuator to maintain its functionality even after one hydraulic failure and two electrical failures. The actuator manifold includes two bypass valves for the hydraulic failure management, which, in case of pressure loss, set in bypass mode the cylinder unit supplied by the failed hydraulic line. The actuator control electronics, as illustrated in Fig. 3, implements two position closed-loop controls, on actuator rod and servovalve spool, respectively. Fig. 2
Hydraulic scheme of the tested flight actuator Fig. 3
Flight actuator closed-loop control

The integration of the flight actuator with the test rig has required the solution of some hydraulic, mechanical and control concerns. The actuator working fluid (MIL-H-5606B) was different from that of the load system; so, a dedicated two-line portable pump has been used for its hydraulic supply. In addition, to eliminate possible backlash effects on the actuator hinges, both the rear and the aft links with the test rig have been obtained via cone bushing joints, Fig. 4. Concerning the actuator control, a MATLAB-Simulink-xPC Target real-time system has been set up [12], essentially composed of an actuator control unit for the input/output and the failures injection, and two PCs networked with a transmission control protocol/internet protocol connection: a host PC for the prototyping of the loop closure model, the data logging and the test management, and a target PC for the real-time execution of the actuator closed-loop control.

sec.title: 2.3.1 Flight actuator flowrate absorption
sec.p: As reported by Table 1, the portable pump used for the hydraulic supply of the flight actuator had a limited power rating; so, the first issue about the test feasibility was related to the actuator flowrate absorption. Actually, during stiffness vibratory tests, the actuator motion is expected to be characterized by small displacements, but also high frequency. In these conditions, the flowrate absorption can be relevant, and an undesirable system coupling could result if the maximum pump flowrate is overcome.

The basic difficulty in assessing the feasibility of the stiffness tests in terms of flow absorption derives from the fact that the flowrate absorption depends on the actuator stiffness response itself. Let us consider the simplified scheme of a symmetric hydraulic actuator reported in Fig. 5: disregarding the fluid leakages (both external and cross-chambers), the flowrate entering the extraction chamber is given by equation (1) (1) where Aa is the actuator pushing area, Sa the actuator stroke, β the fluid bulk modulus, and Pae the fluid pressure in the extraction chamber, while Xa and X·a are the displacement and the velocity of the actuator piston, respectively. The fluid pressure is clearly related to the force applied to the actuator via the piston momentum equation, which (disregarding friction forces) is provided by equation (2) (2) where Par is the pressure in the retraction chamber, Ma the piston mass, and Fext the external load. sec.title: 2.3.2 Load system dynamic capability
sec.p:
Another important issue about the test feasibility was related to the load system dynamic capability, with particular reference to the linearity of the load signal, to the load control bandwidth, and to the rig stiffness. To assess these aspects, the rig configuration has been modified as shown in Fig. 7: a rigid bar long as the actuator at mid-stroke (reference condition for the stiffness tests) substitutes the flight actuator, and the load actuator is commanded to apply a 5-kN sine-wave load (see section 3.2 for procedure details). During the test, the load-induced displacement of the rig parts has been measured by the integrated position transducer of the load actuator. Fig. 7
Experimental set-up for testing the load system dynamic capability

Figure 8 reports a result of this experiment: the load system exhibits satisfactory linearity (perfectly sinusoidal load wave) and good bandwidth. Figure 9 reports the results in terms of rig stiffness. It can be noted that the stiffness increases with frequency, following, for the displacement-to-force response, a first-order behaviour (i.e. the inverse of the stiffness transfer function has a pole at about 11 Hz). The rig stiffness values range from 165 kN/mm at 1 Hz to 950 kN/mm at 70 Hz. To evaluate possible elastic couplings between the tested actuator and the load system, these values must be compared with those expected for the flight actuator. A position-controlled servo-hydraulic actuator is typically very stiff in the low-frequency range [13], with values that can be similar and even greater than the ones measured for the load system. On the other hand, the actuator stiffness decreases with frequency. In particular, in the high-frequency range, it tends to be essentially related to the stiffness of the oil entrapped in the actuator cylinder [13], which, for the flight actuator in single unit operation, is predicted to be about 40 kN/mm (section 3.4). For these reasons, no couplings are expected in the high-frequency range (>10 Hz), while coupling effects can be present for the tests at low frequencies. Fig. 8

sec.title: 3.1 Flight actuator operative modes and test plan definition
sec.p: To explain the rationale of the test plan definition, some preliminary considerations about the flight actuator operative modes must be done.

Being the actuator capable to operate with up to one hydraulic failure and two electrical failures, there are generally 18 possible operative modes3 for the system: the normal one, 4 fail-operative modes related to single failures, 7 to double failures, and 6 to triple failures. It could be argued that the performance characterization in case of multiple failures is less relevant, since the related probability of occurrence is expected to be quite lower than that of the single events, but this is not strictly true if there are ‘dormant’ (i.e. undetected) failures. This is the case of the short circuit of a DDV coil, whose detection can be unfeasible via in-flight monitoring (coil voltage sensors should be available) as well as difficult via pre-flight monitoring [14].

To better clarify, let us assume the failure rates for all the three actuator faults to be λF, and that the maintenance checks suitable for detecting the dormant failures (i.e. the short circuits) are performed with a time interval ΔtMC: at the end of a mission lasting TM, the probability of occurrence of a fail-operative mode characterized by nF failures is given by equation (9) (9) where nDF is the number of dormant failures.

Table 2 shows an example of probability of occurrence results obtained by imposing a 10−4 per flight hour failure rate (reasonable value for practical cases), a 1-h mission duration (typical for fighter aircrafts) and a maintenance interval of 500 flight hours. The dramatic effect of the dormant failures can be noted. The probability of occurrence of the single failure modes changes from probable to remote depending on the failure is a short circuit or not; in addition, the double failure modes can be considered improbable only if no short circuits are present, but they can become remote and even occasional if one or two short circuits occur. sec.title: 3.2 Test procedure
sec.p:
The actuator stiffness tests have been carried out following this procedure.
The load actuator is set in bypass operation (no load applied).
The flight actuator is installed on the test rig and commanded to hold the mid-stroke position.
The test setting is defined via the actuator control unit.
The load control is activated and a load frequency response from 2 to 70 Hz is performed. The amplitude of the load actuator command is modulated up to obtain a 5-kN load amplitude on the force feedback.
During the test, the flight actuator displacement is measured by means of its integrated position transducer.
After the test, for each test frequency, the amplitude and the phase of the actuator stiffness response are calculated using the first terms of the Fourier approximations of the load and the displacement signals.

sec.title: 3.3 Actuator transfer functions and failure effect prediction
sec.p: To provide a physical interpretation of the experimental results, a simplified LTI model of the flight actuator dynamics has been developed and analysed [15]. In general, the relationship between the displacement (xa), the command (xai), and the external load (fext) in a position-controlled actuator is characterized by the stiffness (Ka) and the position response (La) transfer functions, equation (10) (10)
In case of a hydraulic actuator with a servovalve characterized by a second-order dynamics,4 the two actuator transfer functions are given by equations (11) and (12) [13, 15] (11) (12)

The position response behaves as a third-order system, while the stiffness exhibits a zero-order response, in which the closed-loop system poles, appearing as zeros by definition of the stiffness transfer function (equation (10)), interact with the servovalve poles (ωv, ζv) and with the low-frequency pole related to the chambers’ pressurization (ph). The steady-state stiffness response (i.e. the low-frequency asymptote Ka0) depends on both the servovalve pressure gain and the actuator pushing areas, while the high-frequency asymptote is given by the stiffness of the oil entrapped in the actuator chambers, equation (13) (13)

Equation (13), which is always valid for hydraulic actuators, can be demonstrated by means of equation (6). In the high-frequency range, the actuator servovalve response is strongly attenuated, so that the valve ports can be considered closed and the flowrate entering the actuator chambers (qa) zero. Equation (6) being valid for any actuator motion (xa), it means that, in these conditions, the actuator stiffness (Ka) must equal the oil stiffness (Koil).

Obviously, the parameters of the actuator transfer functions Ka and La depend, besides on the hydraulic, mechanical, and control characteristics of the actuator, on its operative mode. The effects on actuator transfer functions due to hydraulic and short circuit failures can be predicted as follows.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Hydraulic failure effects
sec.p: In case of pressure loss at one of the two hydraulic plants, the related unit of the tandem cylinder is automatically set in bypass mode (Fig. 2), and the load capability of the actuator is reduced for the diminution of the actuator pushing areas. The bypass flow in the failed unit also implies an increased damping in the piston dynamics, but this aspect is minor, since the generated damping forces are small with respect to the load capability of the active unit.

The major effects of this failure on the actuator transfer functions are as follows.
Decrease of the steady-state stiffness response The pressure variation in the actuator's chambers needed for counteracting a static external load is higher with respect to the normal mode: a larger valve displacement is thus necessary, which means that the actuator works with a greater closed-loop position error (Fig. 3). For this reason, the low-frequency asymptote in the stiffness response (Ka0 in equation (12)) lowers.
2. Decrease of the oil stiffness

The diminution of the actuator pushing areas induced by the hydraulic failure directly impact on oil stiffness, so that the high-frequency asymptote in the stiffness response lowers. The expression of the oil stiffness for a tandem cylinder working at mid-stroke (reference condition for the tests) is given by equation (14) (14) where nAU is the number of active hydraulic units, β the oil bulk modulus, Sa the stroke, and Aae (i) and Aar (i) the extraction and retraction pushing areas of the ith hydraulic unit, respectively.

It is worth noting that in the reference flight actuator, the pushing areas of the two cylinder units are different (Fig. 2); so, three possible values of oil stiffness can be obtained from equation (14).

sec.title: 3.3.2 Short circuit effects
sec.p: In case of a short circuit, the static force capability of the DDV motor lowers (loss of coil voltage control); moreover, the current circulation in the failed coil depends on the back-electromotive forces induced by the valve spool motion; so, the failed section of the DDV motor works as a ‘brake’ in the spool dynamics [14].

The major effects of this failure on the actuator transfer functions are as follows.
Decreased servovalve bandwidth

From the closed-loop control perspective, the lowering of the DDV motor force capability induced by the short circuit can be viewed as a diminution of the servovalve position control gain. Thus, the valve pulsation (ωv in equation (12)) lowers.
Increased servovalve damping
The ‘brake effect’ induced by the shorted coil implies damping forces in the valve spool dynamics. Thus, the valve damping factor (ζv in equation (12)) increases.

sec.title: 3.4 Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figures 10 to 12 show some examples of the stiffness test results, while Fig. 13 reports all the obtained experimental data in terms of frequency responses. Fig. 10
Flight actuator stiffness: test at 5 Hz (setting A) Fig. 11
Flight actuator stiffness: test at 15 Hz (setting A) Fig. 12
Flight actuator stiffness: test at 55 Hz (setting A) Fig. 13
Flight actuator stiffness frequency responses

The results point out that the stiffness is high at low frequency (Fig. 10), decreases in the intermediate frequency range (Fig. 11), and tends to increase again at high frequencies (Fig. 12). The responses are essentially linear for frequencies greater than 10 Hz, while higher harmonic components, related to friction nonlinearities, come out at low frequencies.

The structure of the stiffness transfer function provided by equation (12) allows one to understand the ‘stiffness hollow’ at about 10 Hz (Fig. 13), which is common to all test settings. The phenomenon is generally observable when a high bandwidth is required to a DDV hydraulic actuator, and it results from the interaction between the servovalve poles (ωv, ζv) and the actuator dominant complex-conjugated poles (ωa, ζa), which are characterized by different damping factors (ζa < ζv) and different pulsations (ωa < ωv).

The discussion presented in section 3.3 helps to interpret the experimental data. To simplify the analysis, consider the stiffness results for the setting A (symmetrical unit active, no electrical failure) as the reference data: the minimum stiffness, occurring at 15 Hz, is 19.5 kN/mm, while the asymptotical high-frequency stiffness is 39 kN/mm.

The response for the setting B (asymmetrical unit active, no electrical failure) is characterized by the increase of both the high-frequency asymptote (45 kN/mm) and the minimum stiffness (28 kN/mm): this results from the increase of the actuator pushing areas, which boosts both oil and steady-state stiffnesses. It is worth noting that if the pushing area difference is not excessive among the tandem units (most applications), the variation of the actuator dominant poles induced by the hydraulic failure is minor. This is pointed out by the phase responses in Fig. 13, which are very similar for the settings A and B.

The results of the setting C (symmetrical unit active, short circuit at one of the four DDV coils) instead points out that the high-frequency asymptote is the same of the setting A, but both the minimum stiffness (16 kN/mm) and the frequency for minimum stiffness (10 Hz) decrease. This is because the oil stiffness for the two settings is identical, but the servovalve dynamics exhibits lowered bandwidth and increased damping.

Concerning the reliability of the test results with respect to the flowrate absorption issues, no hydraulic coupling has been noticed during the study (Fig. 14). In particular, the limited flowrate absorption obtained during the tests highlights that the actuator stiffness characterization could be extended to the tandem operation in the future developments of the research. Fig. 14
Flight actuator flow absorption during the stiffness tests

sec.title: 3.5 Actuator stiffness and FCS dynamic characteristics
sec.p: As discussed in section 1, the actuator stiffness characterization is crucial for the closed-loop design and verification of a FBW/FCS with respect to aeroservoelastic concerns. Typically, the actuator is the less stiff part of the servoelastic system linking the aerodynamic control surface with the aircraft frame, equation (15)4 (15)

Thus, in the frequency range where the actuator stiffness response roughly exhibits no phase delay (>10 Hz, Fig. 13), the stiffness variation can be viewed as the variation of the resonant frequency of the whole servoelastic system (ωse), equation (16)5 (16)

The experimental data show that, depending on load frequency and failures, the actuator stiffness can vary from 16 to 54 kN/mm in the high-frequency range (>10 Hz). In addition, considering that the oil stiffness for the normal operative mode is expected to be 84 kN/mm (sum of the stiffness provided by the units, equation (14)), the resonant frequency of the servoelastic system can roughly double during operation.

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSION
sec.p: The stiffness response of a fault-tolerant FBW actuator for the primary flight controls of a modern jet trainer has been experimentally characterized by carrying out vibratory load tests. The feasibility concerns of the study have been discussed, pointing out possible hydraulic and structural couplings between the test system and the flight actuator. The stiffness tests have been carried out in the frequency range from 2 to 70 Hz at 5-kN load amplitude, and with reference to three fail-operative modes of the actuator: hydraulic failure to one of the two units of the tandem cylinder, and (added) one electrical failure at one of the four servovalve coils. The characteristics of the stiffness response have been interpreted by means of an LTI model of the flight actuator, identifying the structure of the stiffness transfer function, the dynamic interactions that can imply ‘hollows’ in the stiffness response, and pointing out the effects that the hydraulic and electrical failures induce on the actuator performances.
